name: Corn DDGS (hi-pro)
warning: Lysine is limiting amino acid - requires supplementation. Variable nutrient content based on corn source and processing. Risk of mycotoxin contamination (aflatoxin, DON, fumonisin) - test every batch. High fat content can oxidize if not stabilized with antioxidants. High fiber from distillers grains can affect pellet quality.
regulatory_note: FDA approved feed ingredient. Must meet AAFCO specifications for crude protein (min 28%), fat (min 5%), and fiber (max 12%). Mycotoxin limits: <20 ppb aflatoxin, <5 ppm DON for swine. Phosphorus availability >85% must be declared. Grain origin must be declared per FDA requirements.
notes: Most abundant co-product from US ethanol industry. High-protein (>30% CP) and low-fat (<8% fat) varieties available. Excellent phosphorus source (>85% digestible). Can replace soybean meal + corn combination in most diets. Use crystalline lysine to balance amino acids. Test for sulfur content (can be high from sulfuric acid use).

name: Bakery meal
warning: Extremely variable composition based on source bakery products. Can contain high salt (>1.5% NaCl), sugar, and preservatives. Risk of rancidity from high fat. May contain chocolate or other prohibited ingredients for ruminants. Quality control critical. Mycotoxin risk if old/stale products used.
regulatory_note: FDA approved feed ingredient. Must be from approved bakery sources. Maximum salt content must be declared if >0.5%. Prohibited ingredients (chocolate, meat products) cannot be included per BSE regulations. Must meet AAFCO specifications for processed grain products. BSE compliance documentation required.
notes: Composition varies: bread, cookies, crackers, etc. Salt content can be high - check each batch. Excellent energy source similar to corn. Fat can be 8-15% depending on sources. Generally very palatable. Screen for foreign objects and packaging materials.

name: Citrus pulp (dried)
warning: Extremely high calcium (22.5 g/kg) creates severe Ca:P imbalance (>18:1) causing urinary calculi in male ruminants. Contains limonene and essential oils that can cause feed refusal if >15% inclusion. High pectin content can cause digestive upset. Low energy density. Tannins (2.8%) bind proteins.
regulatory_note: FDA approved byproduct feed. Maximum inclusion 20% in ruminant diets to prevent urinary calculi. Calcium level must be declared (>20 g/kg). Must be dried to <10% moisture to prevent mold. Not permitted in poultry starter feeds (<21 days). Mycotoxin risk if moldy fruit processed.
notes: Byproduct of orange/lemon juice processing. Unpalatable at high inclusion - introduce gradually. Pectin is highly fermentable in rumen producing propionate. Good source of digestible fiber (60% NDF digestibility). Counteract high calcium with phosphorus and salt supplementation.

name: Cottonseed meal (de-gossypol)
warning: Contains gossypol pigment - must be from de-gossypol solvent extraction or glandless cotton varieties. Free gossypol must be <100 ppm for pigs, <400 ppm for poultry. Can cause cardiac and testicular damage at high levels. Glandless varieties are safer but less available. High phytic acid reduces mineral availability.
regulatory_note: FDA approved but restricted. Must specify free gossypol content. Maximum free gossypol: 100 ppm for swine, 400 ppm for poultry. Not permitted in calf replacers. Must be from glandless cotton or de-gossypol process. Phytase supplementation recommended. BSE-free certification required.
notes: Glandless cotton varieties eliminate gossypol issue. Solvent extraction reduces free gossypol to <0.02%. Excellent protein quality, low fiber. Higher inclusion possible with glandless types. Monitor for aflatoxin contamination. Good phosphorus source (>70% digestible) when phytase added.

name: Peanut skins (tannin-managed)
warning: Very high tannin content (4.8%) severely limits use in monogastrics - can cause protein binding, reduced growth, and feed refusal. Tannin-managed varieties have <2% tannins but are rare. Risk of aflatoxin contamination if peanuts were moldy. High fiber reduces digestibility.
regulatory_note: FDA approved but restricted. Tannin content must be declared if >2%. Not permitted in starter feeds without detoxification. Maximum inclusion: 5% for swine and poultry. Must meet aflatoxin limits for peanuts (<20 ppb). Organic status depends on peanut sourcing.
notes: Byproduct of peanut blanching. Very cheap but limited by tannins. Tannin-binding agents (PEG) can improve utilization but not cost-effective. Best used in ruminant diets where tannins can be beneficial (bloat prevention). High inclusion causes dark, sticky feces in poultry.

name: Feather meal (hydrolyzed)
warning: Very high protein (85%) but poor digestibility if not properly hydrolyzed. Heat processing can damage amino acids if too severe. Lysine and methionine limiting. High cystine can be problematic if unbalanced. Unpalatable at high inclusion - use in combination with other proteins. Risk of disease transmission if not properly processed.
regulatory_note: FDA approved but must be properly hydrolyzed (rendered) to destroy pathogens per 21 CFR 589.2000. Must meet Salmonella-free requirements. Processed under 9 CFR 500 regulations. Not permitted in ruminant feeds in some states due to BSE concerns. Specify ruminant-safe sourcing.
notes: Rendered poultry feathers - very sustainable protein source. Proper hydrolysis breaks keratin bonds improving digestibility (>75%). Excellent cystine source. Low palatability requires gradual introduction. Best used at 3-5% in most feeds. Cost-effective compared to fish meal. Must be from BSE-free sources.

name: Meat & bone meal (feed-grade, ruminant-free)
warning: BANNED FOR RUMINANT FEEDING in USA & Canada due to BSE risk (21 CFR 589.2000). Must be from ruminant-free facilities and certified. Very high calcium and phosphorus can imbalance ratios. Fat can oxidize causing rancidity. Quality variable based on raw materials. Risk of pathogens if not properly rendered.
regulatory_note: CANNOT BE FED TO RUMINANTS per FDA BSE prevention regulations. Must be from non-ruminant species (porcine, poultry) only. Must meet AAFCO processing standards (minimum 133°C for 20 min). Salmonella-free certification required. Ash content 25-35% typical. Calcium declaration mandatory.
notes: Feed-grade only - not for pet foods. Excellent calcium and phosphorus source for layers. Should not exceed 15% due to high mineral content. Use in swine finishing diets for bone/structural support. Must have clear ruminant-free supply chain documentation. Quality controlled by ARA (Animal Protein Producers Industry).

name: Poultry by-product meal (feed-grade)
warning: High calcium (75 g/kg) and phosphorus (42 g/kg) can imbalance ratios if inclusion >15%. Fat can oxidize causing rancidity - requires antioxidants. Quality variable based on processing and raw materials. Risk of pathogens if not properly rendered. Unpalatable at high inclusion - use in combination.
regulatory_note: FDA approved per AAFCO standards. Must be properly rendered (minimum 133°C for 20 min) to kill pathogens per 9 CFR 500. Salmonella-free certification required. Ash content 15-25% typical. Must declare calcium and phosphorus content. BSE-free guarantee required for export.
notes: High-quality animal protein from slaughterhouse byproducts (heads, feet, organs). Should not exceed 15% due to high mineral content. Excellent amino acid profile for poultry and fish feeds. Better digestibility than meat & bone meal. More consistent quality than meat & bone meal. Use in grower/finisher swine diets for lean gain.

name: Alfalfa pellets (sun-cured)
warning: Very high calcium (18.5 g/kg) can imbalance Ca:P ratio to >6:1. Contains saponins that can cause bloat in ruminants if >30% of diet. High fiber limits digestibility in monogastrics. Can contain phytoestrogens affecting reproduction. Vitamin D content variable based on sun-curing. Risk of pesticide/herbicide residues.
regulatory_note: FDA approved forage product. Maximum inclusion in swine feeds: 10% to avoid mineral imbalances. Forage source must be declared (sun-cured vs dehy). Pesticide/herbicide testing may be required for organic certification. Calcium content must be declared. Not for fish diets.
notes: Available as sun-cured (lower quality, cheaper) or dehy (dehydrated, higher quality, more expensive). Good source of xanthophylls for yolk color. High protein for a forage but poor amino acid digestibility. Excellent for ruminant roughage. Contains natural antioxidants (vitamin E, carotene).

name: Alfalfa pellets (dehydrated)
warning: High calcium (16.5 g/kg) can imbalance Ca:P ratio. Contains saponins that can cause bloat in ruminants if >35% of diet. Dehydrated form has better nutrient retention than sun-cured. Phytoestrogens may affect reproduction in breeding animals. High quality but more expensive than sun-cured.
regulatory_note: FDA approved. Higher quality than sun-cured due to lower fiber and better protein. Maximum inclusion in swine: 12% to avoid mineral imbalances. Must declare protein quality (dehy vs sun-cured). Pesticide testing for organic. Calcium declaration mandatory. Not for fish diets.
notes: Dehydrated within hours of harvest for maximum nutrient retention. Higher protein (18-22%) and lower fiber than sun-cured. Better carotene and xanthophyll content. More consistent quality. Premium forage ingredient. Excellent for dairy cows - high bypass protein fraction.

name: Rapeseed meal (low-GSL)
warning: Contains glucosinolates (12 μmol/g limit for low-GSL varieties). Must be from double-zero (00) varieties. Can cause thyroid enlargement and reduced growth if GSL >15 μmol/g. High fiber in seed coat reduces digestibility. Erucic acid content must be <2% in oil.
regulatory_note: EU Register of Feed Materials approved. Must be from low-glucosinolate varieties (<18 μmol/g total GSL). Maximum erucic acid in oilseed meals: 2%. Not permitted in organic feed if solvent-extracted. Phytase supplementation recommended.
notes: Double-zero varieties (low GSL <12 μmol/g, low erucic acid) are standard in EU. Excellent amino acid profile for plant protein. Heat treatment (toasting) improves digestibility and reduces GSL. Cost-effective alternative to soybean meal.

name: Sunflower expeller (hi-pro)
warning: Lysine is limiting amino acid. High fiber content reduces digestibility in young animals. Chlorogenic acid can oxidize, causing feed refusal. Phytic acid reduces mineral bioavailability. Oil content prone to rancidity if not stabilized.
regulatory_note: EU approved feed material. Must meet specifications for crude fiber (max 18%) and fat (min 12% for hi-fat, 5-8% for deoiled). Phytase recommended for monogastric diets. Not permitted in organic if solvent-extracted.
notes: Available as high-protein (38-40% CP, 15% CF) or low-protein (32-34% CP, 22% CF). Hi-pro version is dehulled with higher digestibility. Good selenium source for European diets. Toasting improves protein quality and reduces oxidation.

name: Beet pulp (dried)
warning: Very high calcium (11.5 g/kg) can imbalance Ca:P ratio to >10:1, causing urinary calculi in male ruminants and zinc deficiency. Must be soaked before feeding to prevent choke. Can cause diarrhea if introduced too rapidly. Low phosphorus content requires supplementation.
regulatory_note: EU approved feed material (Register 002327). Maximum inclusion 25% in ruminant diets to maintain mineral balance. Must declare calcium content on label. Recommended Ca:P ratio must not exceed 3:1 in complete diet. Not for fish diets due to high calcium.
notes: Excellent pectin source (25% of fiber) - highly fermentable in rumen. Good energy from volatile fatty acids. Soak in water 1:2 ratio for 30 minutes before feeding. Can replace 25% of hay in dairy rations. Very palatable and reduces sorting in TMR.

name: Distillers wheat grains
warning: Lysine is limiting amino acid. High phosphorus availability (>80%) requires calcium supplementation. Sulfur content can be high - monitor for polioencephalomalacia in ruminants if sulfur >0.4% of diet. Variable nutrient content based on wheat quality and distillation process.
regulatory_note: EU approved co-product (Register 002505). Must meet specifications for protein, fiber, and ash. High phosphorus availability declared on label. Maximum sulfur content: 0.5% in complete feed. Mycotoxin testing required if wheat was of suspect quality.
notes: Excellent alternative to corn DDGS in wheat-growing regions. Lower fat than corn DDGS reduces rancidity risk. High digestible fiber (65% NDFd) excellent for dairy cows. Can replace soybean meal + cereal grain combination. Protein quality improves with amino acid supplementation.

name: Pea hulls
warning: Very high fiber (50% minimum) and extremely low energy. Very bulky - can reduce feed intake if inclusion too high. Dusty - respiratory irritant during handling. Very low digestibility for monogastrics. Risk of pesticide residues if not organic.
regulatory_note: EU approved as fiber source (Register 013171). Maximum 10% in ruminant complete feeds, 5% in pig feeds, 3% in poultry feeds. Must be free from mycotoxin contamination. Low energy content must be declared on label. Not for fish feeds.
notes: Byproduct of pea protein isolation. Pure insoluble fiber (cellulose). Very low fermentability (slow fermentation rate) good for gut motility without excessive gas production. Used in diabetic pet foods for low glycemic impact. Good for hairball control in rabbits.

name: Faba bean meal (tannin-managed)
warning: Low methionine content requires supplementation. Contains vicine/convicine in colored-flower varieties that can cause favism (hemolysis) in sensitive animals. Tannin-managed varieties (white-flowering) reduce this risk. Trypsin inhibitors reduce protein digestibility. Must be heat-treated.
regulatory_note: EU approved (Register 000608). Must be from low-tannin varieties (white/cream flowers). Vicine/convicine content must be <0.1% in monogastric feeds. Heat processing required to inactivate trypsin inhibitors. Organic approved if sourced from organic farms.
notes: Tannin-managed (zero-tannin) varieties have white flowers. Traditional varieties with colored flowers have high tannins and vicine/convicine. Excellent protein quality for European-grown legume. Good amino acid profile except methionine. Fermentation improves digestibility.

name: Lupin meal (sweet varieties)
warning: Low methionine and cystine content requires supplementation. Contains alkaloids (sparteine, lupanine) in bitter varieties - must use sweet/low-alkaloid varieties only. High fiber (16%) limits use in young poultry. Trypsin inhibitors reduce protein digestibility. Must be heat-treated.
regulatory_note: EU approved (Register 000688). Must be from sweet/low-alkaloid varieties (<0.02% total alkaloids). Alkaloid content must be declared. Heat processing required to inactivate trypsin inhibitors. Organic approved. Maximum fiber: 18% for poultry feeds.
notes: Sweet lupins (L. albus, L. angustifolius) have <0.02% alkaloids. White lupin has highest protein (36-38%). Australian sweet lupins most common. Good amino acid profile except sulfur amino acids. Fermentation or enzyme treatment improves digestibility. Sustainable European protein source.

name: Brewer's spent grain
warning: Moisture content in fresh form 78% - must be used within 3-5 days or dried. Contains residual hop compounds that can reduce palatability. High fiber can cause digestive upset if introduced too rapidly. Lysine limiting. Risk of spoilage and mycotoxin growth in warm weather.
regulatory_note: EU approved co-product (Register 013171). Fresh form requires HACCP for short shelf-life management. Dried form must have moisture <12%. Mycotoxin testing recommended. Not for fish diets due to high fiber and hop residues. Must meet microbiological standards.
notes: Major co-product from European brewing industry. Very cost-effective protein source. Wet form requires local sourcing. Dried form is stable and transportable. Good source of B-vitamins from yeast. Fiber digestibility 55-60% in rumen. Can replace 30% of concentrate in dairy rations.

name: Shea nut cake
warning: Extremely high tannin content (8.2%) severely limits use in monogastrics. Tannins bind proteins and reduce digestibility. Contains saponins and other bitter compounds. Can reduce palatability and feed intake. Must be processed (fermentation/extraction) to reduce tannins.
regulatory_note: Limited approval as feed ingredient. High tannin varieties restricted to ruminants only. Detoxification required for monogastric use. Maximum tannin content: 1% for poultry, 2% for pigs if detoxified. Not permitted in EU organic feed.
notes: Byproduct of shea butter extraction. Very limited nutritional value due to tannins. Ruminants can tolerate higher levels due to tannin-protein complex formation in rumen. Consider chemical analysis before each batch. Very variable nutrient content.

name: Baobab seed meal
warning: High tannin content (2.8%) reduces protein digestibility. Contains phytic acid that reduces mineral bioavailability. Must be processed (fermented/extruded) to improve nutrient availability. Variable nutrient content based on tree age and processing.
regulatory_note: Traditional feed ingredient in Africa. Novel in EU and USA. Detoxification may be required for high inclusion rates. Maximum tannin content: 1.5% for monogastrics if processed. Heavy metal testing recommended.
notes: Exceptional calcium content from seed coat. Good energy source (44.6% NFE). Processing (dehulling, cooking) reduces tannins and phytic acid. Potential prebiotic effects from soluble fiber. Sustainable use of underutilized African tree crop.

name: Jatropha kernel cake (detox, research-only)
warning: RESEARCH ONLY - NOT FOR COMMERCIAL FEED. Contains phorbol esters that are toxic to monogastrics and potentially toxic to ruminants. Can cause severe diarrhea, liver/kidney damage, and mortality. Detoxification not yet commercially viable. Extreme caution required.
regulatory_note: NOT APPROVED for commercial feed. Research use only with full safety protocols. Ph.Eur. includes jatropha oil as toxic substance. Multiple jurisdictions prohibit use in animal feed. Requires regulatory exemption for research.
notes: NOT FOR COMMERCIAL FORMULATION. High protein content is attractive but toxins make it unsafe. Current research on biological/chemical detoxification. Multiple research institutions investigating safety. DO NOT USE IN PRODUCTION FEEDS.

name: Bambara groundnut meal
warning: Contains trypsin inhibitors, tannins, and phytic acid. Requires heat treatment (cooking/roasting) to improve protein digestibility. Hard-to-cook phenomenon requires extended cooking time. Dark seed coats have higher tannin content.
regulatory_note: Traditional African food/feed ingredient. Approved in most jurisdictions. Processing required to reduce anti-nutritional factors. Low-tannin varieties (white/cream seeds) preferred for monogastrics. Must meet grain legume quality standards.
notes: Underutilized African legume with good nutritional profile. High in lysine compared to other legumes. Soaking and cooking reduces ANFs by 60-70%. Drought tolerant crop - good for climate resilience. Variable tannin content based on seed coat color.

name: Cowpea haulms
warning: High fiber content limits digestibility in monogastrics. Risk of aflatoxin contamination if not properly dried. Should be harvested at pod maturity for optimal quality. Contains moderate tannins that reduce protein digestibility.
regulatory_note: Approved forage ingredient in most jurisdictions. Must meet forage quality standards. Moisture content must be <13% for storage. Mycotoxin testing required in humid regions. Considered safe for all livestock classes when properly processed.
notes: Dual-purpose legume - grain for human/feed, haulms for fodder. Better protein quality than cereal straws. Sun-drying within 48 hours critical for quality. Can be used as silage when mixed with grasses. Not suitable for high-producing animals as sole forage.

name: Sorghum malt sprout
warning: Contains moderate trypsin inhibitors that reduce protein digestibility. Tannins from sorghum can reduce palatability. Variable nutrient content based on malting process and sorghum variety. Risk of mycotoxin contamination if sorghum was moldy.
regulatory_note: Approved brewing byproduct. Must meet specifications for protein, fiber, and ash. Mycotoxin testing recommended if sourced from suspect grain. Trypsin inhibitor activity should be <10 TUI/mg protein.
notes: Good protein source for the price. Contains residual amylases from malting process. Fiber is partially fermentable. Better feeding value than raw sorghum due to enzyme activation. Can replace soybean meal up to 25% in grower pig diets with amino acid supplementation.

name: Millet bran
warning: High fiber content (22.5%) can limit digestibility in young monogastrics. Contains phytic acid that reduces mineral bioavailability. Tannins present in some varieties reduce protein digestibility. Risk of mycotoxin contamination if stored damp.
regulatory_note: Approved cereal byproduct. Must meet bran quality standards. Mycotoxin testing required for products from suspect regions. Phytase supplementation recommended for monogastric diets. Maximum fiber: 25% for poultry.
notes: Better protein quality than wheat bran. Pearl millet bran preferred over finger millet due to lower tannins. Good source of B-vitamins and minerals. Fermentable fiber beneficial for gut health. Can replace 20-30% of cereal grains in finishing diets.

name: Groundnut shells (fiber)
warning: Extremely high fiber (65%) makes it indigestible for monogastrics. Very low nutritional value. Can cause impaction if fed at high levels. Dusty - respiratory irritant. Must be ground for ruminants to improve utilization.
regulatory_note: Approved as roughage source only. Not permitted as primary feed ingredient for monogastrics. Must be free from aflatoxin contamination. Maximum inclusion in complete feeds: 5% for poultry, 3% for pigs.
notes: Very cheap fiber source for ruminants in peanut-growing regions. Can be used as bedding and then fed. Better utilized when ammoniated or treated with alkali. Not suitable for high-producing animals. Consider transportation cost vs. nutritional value.

name: Sunflower cake (high fiber)
warning: High fiber content (28%) limits digestibility, especially in young monogastrics. Lysine is limiting amino acid. Contains chlorogenic acid that can oxidize and reduce palatability. High fiber can cause pellet quality issues. Phytic acid reduces mineral availability.
regulatory_note: Approved oilseed meal. Must meet specifications for crude fiber (max 30%), fat (min 5%), and protein (min 26%). Phytase supplementation recommended for monogastric diets. Not permitted for fish in EU due to fiber content.
notes: Available as high-fiber (dehulled) or low-fiber varieties. High-fiber version is cheaper but less digestible. Good methionine content for poultry. Heat treatment (toasted) improves digestibility and reduces oxidation. Popular in sunflower-growing regions of Southern Africa.

name: Brewer's spent grain (dried)
warning: High moisture content in fresh form (75-80%) causes rapid spoilage. Dried form is stable but bulky. Contains residual bitter compounds from hops that can reduce palatability. High fiber can cause digestive upset if inclusion too high. Risk of mycotoxin contamination if storage inadequate.
regulatory_note: Approved brewing byproduct. Must be stabilized to prevent spoilage. Mycotoxin testing recommended. Fresh form requires on-farm feeding within 3-5 days. Dried form has longer shelf life. Not permitted in organic feed if hops were non-organic.
notes: Wet form (75-80% moisture) is very cheap but logistics challenging. Dried form increases cost but improves storability. Good rumen bypass protein for dairy cattle. Can partially replace forage in ruminant diets due to fiber digestibility (55-60% NDFd).

name: Copra expeller (high fat)
warning: High in medium-chain saturated fatty acids (lauric, myristic). Low in lysine and other essential amino acids. Contains mannan polysaccharides that increase digesta viscosity. Risk of rancidity due to high oil content. High fiber reduces pellet quality.
regulatory_note: Approved feed ingredient. Must specify fat content (high fat = >8% residual oil). Quality parameter: maximum 12% crude fiber. Must meet ash specifications (<7%).
notes: Also available as low-fat variant (<5% oil). High-fat version provides energy but reduces pellet durability. Good rumen bypass protein source for dairy cattle.

name: Rice bran (stabilized)
warning: Unstabilized rice bran can become rancid within days due to lipase activity. High phytic acid reduces mineral bioavailability. Contains trypsin inhibitor. High oil content may cause soft carcass fat in pigs. Risk of aflatoxin contamination.
regulatory_note: Must be stabilized to prevent rancidity (FFA <10%). Meets FDA requirements for rice bran products. Phytase supplementation recommended for monogastric diets. Must meet mycotoxin standards.
notes: Stabilization via heating or extrusion inactivates lipase. De-oiled version also available. Excellent source of B-vitamins and oryzanol. High phosphorus requires calcium supplementation. Most widely used rice byproduct in Southeast Asia.

name: Cassava chip meal (detoxified)
warning: Must be properly detoxified to reduce cyanogenic glycosides (linamarin) to <10 mg/kg HCN equivalent. Inadequate processing can release lethal cyanide. Test every batch for residual cyanide. Dusty - respiratory risk during handling. Low protein quality.
regulatory_note: Must comply with CODEX STAN 238 (sweet cassava <50 mg/kg cyanide). Detoxification process must be validated. HACCP protocol required for cyanide control. Not permitted for piglets or starter poultry without certification.
notes: Primary energy source replacement for corn. Sun-drying followed by water soaking for 24h reduces cyanide by 80%. Fermentation further reduces cyanide. High starch digestibility (>90%). Very economical in Southeast Asia.

name: Sago palm meal
warning: Very bulky with low bulk density. Low protein and micronutrient content. High fiber reduces digestibility in monogastrics. Quality variable based on processing method. May contain residual bark/contaminants if poorly processed.
regulatory_note: Generally recognized as safe (GRAS) for livestock feed. Quality standards vary by country. Must be free from palm bark and other contaminants. Maximum ash content: 4%.
notes: Produced from sago palm starch extraction waste. Lower energy than cassava due to higher fiber. Best for ruminants where fiber is beneficial. Limited micronutrient content requires vitamin/mineral premix supplementation.

name: Duckweed fresh/meal
warning: Quality highly variable based on growing conditions and nutrient media. Risk of heavy metal contamination if grown in polluted water. Must be grown in controlled conditions or tested for contaminants. Fresh duckweed spoils rapidly - must be dried within 24 hours.
regulatory_note: Not currently approved as commercial feed ingredient in EU or USA. Requires Novel Food/Feed assessment. Heavy metal testing mandatory if sourced from natural water bodies. Maximum inclusion limits apply to dried form only.
notes: Grown on nutrient-rich wastewater in controlled systems. Exceptional protein quality comparable to soybean meal. Very high mineral content may require diet reformulation. Fresh form has 92-94% moisture, dried form 8-10% moisture.

name: Seaweed meal (Ulva spp.)
warning: High iodine content (>1000 ppm) can cause thyroid dysfunction if >5% inclusion. High ash content (28%) may dilute energy content. Risk of heavy metal bioaccumulation (arsenic, cadmium) if harvested from polluted coastal waters. Test for contaminants.
regulatory_note: Novel feed ingredient requiring pre-market approval in most jurisdictions. Must be harvested from clean water sources with heavy metal testing. Iodine content must be declared on label. EU requires novel food safety assessment.
notes: Excellent source of trace minerals and marine polysaccharides. Ulva (sea lettuce) has better digestibility than Sargassum. High prebiotic fiber content supports gut health. Fresh or dried forms available. Dried form has 90% DM.

name: Sweet potato peels
warning: Contains trypsin inhibitors and small amounts of cyanogenic compounds in fresh peels. Must be heat-treated (cooked/sundried) to reduce anti-nutritional factors. High moisture content can lead to rapid spoilage. Risk of pesticide residues if not organic.
regulatory_note: Approved fruit/vegetable processing byproduct. Must meet pesticide residue limits. Heat treatment required to reduce anti-nutritional factors. Maximum aflatoxin: 20 ppb.
notes: Excellent source of digestible carbohydrates (52% starch). Good energy value for monogastrics. Tannins in peel reduce protein digestibility. Drying at >85°C for 30 minutes eliminates most anti-nutritional factors. Vitamin A precursor content beneficial for poultry.

name: Taro leaves (detox)
warning: Contains calcium oxalate crystals (raphides) that cause oral irritation and kidney damage. Detoxification by cooking/boiling required to dissolve oxalates. High calcium content can imbalance Ca:P ratio. Contains protease inhibitors.
regulatory_note: Must be heat-treated to reduce oxalate toxicity. Maximum calcium oxalate: 0.5%. Not permitted in starter feeds without certification. Must meet pesticide residue standards for leafy vegetables.
notes: Boiling for 30 minutes reduces oxalates by 85%. Excellent calcium source (2.5%). High-quality protein for a leafy material. Use as functional protein in tropical regions. Palatability improved after processing.

name: Water spinach (Ipomoea aquatica)
warning: Fresh form has 88% moisture - spoilage risk high. Contains oxalates and saponins. May accumulate heavy metals if grown in contaminated water. Drying required for storage. Low dry matter yield.
regulatory_note: Generally recognized as safe for livestock feed in Asia-Pacific region. Must meet pesticide residue limits if cultivated commercially. Heavy metal testing recommended for aquatic-sourced material.
notes: Excellent protein source for tropical regions. Very fast-growing (harvest every 21 days). High moisture content makes transport costly. Dried meal is concentrated protein source. Rich in carotenoids for yolk color enhancement.

name: Mustard cake (low-glucosinolate)
warning: Contains glucosinolates that can cause thyroid enlargement and liver damage. Maximum free glucosinolate level: 15 μmol/g. Must be sourced from low-GSL varieties only. Not recommended for fish due to thyroid-disrupting effects.
regulatory_note: Must comply with EU Directive 2002/32/EC on undesirable substances. Maximum glucosinolate content regulated in EU feed. Banned for aquafeed in EU.
notes: Indian low-GSL varieties (e.g., Varuna, Kranti) are preferred. Requires quarterly testing for glucosinolate levels.

name: Groundnut haulms
warning: High fiber forage with low digestibility. Risk of aflatoxin contamination if not properly dried. Should be sun-dried to <12% moisture within 48 hours of harvest.
regulatory_note: Must comply with FDA aflatoxin limits for feed (<20 ppb for dairy cattle). Monitor for Aspergillus contamination in humid climates.
notes: Best used as roughage for ruminants. Protein quality is poor with low lysine. Harvest at pod maturity for optimal nutrient content.

name: Red gram (pigeon pea) husk
warning: Very high fiber, low digestibility. Contains condensed tannins that reduce protein digestibility. Must be processed (ground/extruded) to improve utilization. Risk of mycotoxin contamination if stored improperly.
regulatory_note: Considered as roughage ingredient. Not permitted as primary protein source. Must meet quality standards for fiber sources under EU feed legislation.
notes: Used primarily as fiber source in ruminant diets. Very low energy density. Best suited for gestating cows and dry ewes. Not recommended for high-producing animals.

name: Cottonseed hulls (low gossypol)
warning: Free gossypol content must be <100 ppm for safe feeding to adult ruminants. Zero inclusion for pigs and poultry due to gossypol toxicity. Maximum free gossypol: 0.06% (600 ppm). Monitor for aflatoxin contamination.
regulatory_note: Must meet FDA guidelines for cottonseed products. Free gossypol analysis required for each batch. Not permitted for swine, poultry, or fish feeds in most jurisdictions.
notes: Excellent fiber source for ruminants. Very low nutritional value for monogastrics. Use primarily as roughage extender in drought conditions. Free gossypol content typically 0.04-0.08%.

name: Neem seed cake (detox)
warning: Contains azadirachtin (triterpenoids) and other bitter compounds. Detoxification required via water washing or solvent extraction. Residual azadirachtin can reduce palatability and cause digestive upset. Maximum residual azadirachtin: 100 ppm.
regulatory_note: Novel ingredient in many jurisdictions. Requires safety assessment and registration. Detoxification process must be validated. Not permitted in EU organic feed.
notes: Detoxification reduces anti-nutritional factors by 70-80%. Use as protein supplement in ruminant diets. Monitor for residual pesticides used in neem cultivation.

name: Tamarind seed meal (detox)
warning: Contains high levels of condensed tannins (3.2%) that can bind proteins and reduce digestibility. Detoxification required via water extraction or fermentation. Test for residual cyanogenic compounds. Maximum tannin content: 3.5%.
regulatory_note: Novel ingredient in many regions. Requires safety assessment. Detoxification process must be validated and documented. Monitor for Salmonella contamination during processing.
notes: Detoxification reduces tannin content by 60-70%. Good energy source due to high starch content. Use as partial replacement for cereal grains in monogastric diets.

name: Karanja cake (detox)
warning: Contains karanjin, pongamia oil, and other furano-flavonoids that are toxic to monogastrics. Detoxification via water/ethanol extraction required. Residual toxicity can cause liver damage and reduced growth. Test for residual karanjin.
regulatory_note: Restricted ingredient in EU and USA. Requires pre-market approval. Detoxification must be certified. Maximum karanjin residue: 100 ppm. Not permitted in organic feed systems.
notes: Similar to neem cake but with different toxic profile. Detoxification reduces ANFs by 65-75%. Use primarily in ruminant diets. Monitor for residual oil content (>8% reduces palatability).

name: De-oiled rice bran (stabilized)
warning: High phytic acid content reduces mineral bioavailability. Requires phytase supplementation for monogastrics. Stabilization prevents rancidity but does not eliminate phytic acid. Contains high phosphorus relative to calcium.
regulatory_note: Widely approved feed ingredient. Stabilization process must prevent free fatty acid formation (<10% FFA). Meets FDA requirements for rice bran products. Phosphorus content requires calcium supplementation.
notes: Stabilization via extrusion or heating prevents rancidity. Good source of B-vitamins and oryzanol. High phosphorus content beneficial for layers but requires calcium balancing. Strongly recommended for ruminant diets.

name: Sorghum DDGS
warning: Lysine is limiting amino acid. Variable nutrient content based on sorghum variety and processing. Risk of mycotoxin contamination (aflatoxin, fumonisin). Test each batch. High fiber content may affect pellet quality.
regulatory_note: Approved feed ingredient in most jurisdictions. Must meet FDA mycotoxin limits (<20 ppb aflatoxin). Nutrient guarantee required for protein, fat, and fiber. Phosphorus availability is high (>80%).
notes: Excellent phosphorus source (>80% digestible). Lower lysine than corn DDGS but good energy value. Use with crystalline lysine supplementation. More variable than corn DDGS due to sorghum tannin content.
